title: Su Song
abstract: Su Song was a Chinese scholar of the Northern Song dynasty, active at the imperial court. He was an astronomer, pharmacologist, engineer, poet, and diplomat, embodying the encyclopedic scholarly tradition of medieval China.

title: Al-Jazari
abstract: A 12th‑century engineer from the Islamic world famous for inventive machines. He designed playful yet accurate water clocks and early automata, mixing art and engineering to measure time. His illustrated treatise spread these ideas widely

title: Giovanni de’ Dondi
abstract: Giovanni Dondi, originally from Padua in Italy, came from a family of clockmakers: his father was one of the first creators of mechanical clocks. He trained at a very young age in this context of technical innovation at the dawn of European clockmaking.

title: Christiaan Huygens
abstract: A Dutch scientist from a cultured family in The Hague. Educated at the University of Leiden in law and mathematics. Supported by his father Constantijn Huygens, he quickly turned toward science and engineering

title: Jean Romilly
abstract: A Geneva-born clockmaker established in Paris, Jean Romilly became a recognized figure in the technical and intellectual world of the 18th century. A friend of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and close to encyclopedist circles, he integrated into the Enlightenment network while remaining an innovative craftsman

title: Jean Jacques Rousseau
abstract: A philosopher, writer, and musician from Geneva. The son and grandson of clockmakers, Rousseau grew up in an artisanal environment before becoming one of the major figures of the Enlightenment. Exiled, a traveler, and a marginal figure both at court and in the salons.

title: Jean-Antoine Lépine
abstract: Born in Challex (Pays de Gex) and trained by a Geneva clockmaker, Jean-Antoine Lépine settled in Paris at the age of 24. In 1756, he married the daughter of André-Charles Caron, clockmaker to the king, which introduced him to the royal court. Close to Enlightenment circles, he was also Beaumarchais’s brother-in-law and active within the intellectual milieu.

title: Josiah Emery
abstract: Josiah Emery, born in the Canton of Vaud (Switzerland), settled in London where he became a precision clockmaker specializing in the refinement of the lever escapement recently invented by Thomas Mudge.

title: Pierre Frederic Ingold
abstract: A Swiss clockmaker born in La Chaux-de-Fonds, he trained with Breguet in Paris, where he learned his methods and traveled on his behalf. After several failures in Switzerland, France, England, and the United States, he remained an isolated visionary, too far ahead of his time.

title: Henri-Louis Jaquet-Droz
abstract: The son of Pierre Jaquet-Droz, a Swiss clockmaker, Henri-Louis Jaquet-Droz grew up between Neuchâtel and Nancy, where he was trained in mathematics and precision mechanics. He ran a workshop in London, undertook numerous business trips, and then settled in Geneva to found a watchmaking manufacture.

title: Justin Vulliamy
abstract: A Swiss clockmaker from the Pays de Vaud. Trained in Paris, Justin Vulliamy moved to London around 1730 to perfect the cylinder escapement, recently invented by George Graham. Partnered with Benjamin Gray, clockmaker to the court, he became an important figure in British clockmaking.

title: Abraham-Louis Breguet
abstract: Born in Neuchâtel (Switzerland), Abraham-Louis Breguet learned clockmaking from his stepfather, then perfected his craft in Paris under the guidance of Ferdinand Berthoud and Jean-Antoine Lépine. In 1775, he set up on the Quai de l’Horloge in Paris, the nerve center of clockmaking.

title: Honore De Balzac
abstract: A major writer of the 19th century in France, Balzac made watchmaking a recurring literary motif in his work, where watches and clocks became powerful symbols.

title: John Harrison
abstract: A self-taught carpenter from Yorkshire, John Harrison trained himself in clockmaking. From the 1730s onward, he devoted himself entirely to developing a marine chronometer, supported by George Graham and the astronomer Edmond Halley.

title: Ferdinand Berthoud
abstract: Ferdinand Berthoud, originally from the Swiss Jura, was born into a family of clockmakers and notable figures. He learned the trade from his brother in Couvet, then moved to Paris at the age of 18, where he became a clock- and pendulum-maker.

title: John Arnold
abstract: John Arnold was the son of an English clockmaker. A family quarrel drove him to flee at the age of 19 to Holland, then Germany, where he survived as a gunsmith. Upon returning to London, he quickly became famous thanks to his mechanical genius and inventive spirit.

title: Henri Robert Ekegren
abstract: Born in Copenhagen in 1823, Lars Emil Johansen was the son of a Swedish father and a Danish mother. He worked in Denmark, Switzerland, France, and Germany alongside major figures of watchmaking such as Urban and Jules Jürgensen, Winnerl, and Adolph Lange. In 1847, he settled in Geneva, where he became clockmaker to the King of Denmark and co-founded a watchmaking manufacture.

title: Daniel Quare
abstract: An English clockmaker based in London, an influential member of the Clockmakers’ Company. Active at the end of the 17th century, Daniel Quare is recognized as one of the great masters of British clockmaking.

title: Georg Graham
abstract: Originally from Yorkshire and orphaned at a very young age, George Graham went to London as an apprentice. Protected and later the son-in-law of Thomas Tompion, he inherited his workshop in 1713. A distinguished member of the Royal Society, he became a pillar of British scientific clockmaking.

title: Hisashige Tanaka
abstract: Hisashige Tanaka was born in Kurume, in feudal Japan, the eldest son of a tortoiseshell craftsman. From a very young age, he displayed an early mechanical genius. Rather than taking over the family business, he arranged to leave that role to his brother so he could devote himself to his art: karakuri automata and mechanical inventions.

title: Adrien Philippe
abstract: The son of a rural French clockmaker, he was born in La Bazoche-Gouët. Trained in mechanics from a very young age, he left his village at 18 for Le Havre, where he repaired marine chronometers, then worked in London before settling in Paris in 1836. In his pursuit of excellence, he dreamed of restoring luxury watchmaking in the manner of Breguet.

title: Louis Benjamin Audemars
abstract: A Swiss clockmaker born and active in Le Brassus, in the Vallée de Joux, Louis-Benjamin Audemars came from a lineage of artisans. Trained by a master now unknown — perhaps his uncle Daniel Piguet, or Philippe-Samuel Meylan, his future friend and indirect associate — he founded his own company, Louis Audemars, in 1811, starting from Meylan’s workshop.

title: Jules Jurgensen
abstract: Jules Jürgensen, a Danish-born clockmaker, trained in England and later settled in Switzerland, in Le Locle, at the heart of the watchmaking tradition. Unlike his father and brother, he explored new paths and developed an experimental approach.

title: Edouard Koehn
abstract: Born in 1839 in Germany, the son of Karl Koehn, a court clockmaker. He moved to Geneva at the age of 20, where he trained at the School of Watchmaking. Having begun his career as a simple clockmaker, he rose through the ranks at Patek Philippe, becoming director and shareholder in 1876, before founding his own watchmaking house by acquiring the firm of Robert Ekegren.

title: Paul Ditisheim
abstract: Born in La Chaux-de-Fonds, he wanted to become a doctor, but his father steered him toward watchmaking. He entered the School of Watchmaking and, at the age of 23, received a distinction from the British Horological Institute. Despite this, he refused an English career and returned to Switzerland.

title: Galileo Galilei
abstract: Galileo, a Tuscan physicist and astronomer and a major figure of modern science, was active in Italy under the patronage of the Medici. He taught in Padua and maintained connections with scholarly circles throughout Europe.

title: Thomas Tompion
abstract: Originally from Bedfordshire and the son of a blacksmith, Tompion acquired expertise in mechanical precision at an early age. Trained in London, he entered the prestigious Clockmakers’ Company in 1671, quickly becoming a central figure in English clockmaking.

title: Thomas Mudge
abstract: The son of a pastor from Exeter, Thomas Mudge was noticed at a very young age for his dexterity. He was sent to London as an apprentice to George Graham, Tompion’s direct successor. He later became an exceptional independent clockmaker, highly esteemed at the English court.

title: Isaac Thuret
abstract: A renowned Parisian clockmaker, established from 1686 under the Grand Gallery of the Louvre, in the former residence of the painter Charles Errard. His lodging was granted by royal patent — proof of his prestige within the court and scientific circles.

title: From Seasonal Time to Fixed Time
The Rise of the Swiss Jura
The Chronometer that Built an Empire
The Theft of Time in the Factories
The Tuning Fork – Prelude to Electronics
Switzerland on the Brink of Collapse
The Beginnings of the Grande Complication
The Piguet Family – Among the First Settlers
The First Watchmakers of the Vallée de Joux
Hourglass
abstract: An enclosed sand timer that measures short, repeatable intervals for navigation and work.

title: Atomic Clock
abstract: A frequency standard based on atoms that defines modern time for navigation and networks.

title: Egyptian Sundial
abstract: One of the earliest instruments to measure daytime hours using the sun’s shadow. Egyptian sundials structured agricultural work, ritual calendars, and state administration by aligning daily life with celestial rhythms.

title: Greek Gnomon
abstract: A vertical rod used to read the sun’s altitude and mark time, seasons, and geographic latitude. The gnomon helped Greek astronomers quantify the heavens with geometry.

title: Babylonian Water Clock (Clepsydra)
abstract: A regulated flow of water measured equal intervals independent of sunlight. Clepsydrae timed rituals, legal proceedings, and astronomical work in ancient Mesopotamia.

title: Armillary Sphere
abstract: A three-dimensional model of the heavens composed of nested rings. Scholars used it to visualize celestial motions and teach cosmology.

title: Nocturnal
abstract: A hand-held device to tell time at night from circumpolar stars. Mariners used nocturnals when the sun was not visible.

title: Su Song’s Astronomical Clock Tower
abstract: The Chinese scholar Su Song designed a monumental astronomical clock 12 meters high, powered by a waterwheel and composed of about 400 parts. A true cosmic machine, it did more than indicate the time: it represented the movements of the stars, the Earth, and the heavens in a coherent system.

title: Early Mechanical Clock
abstract: Weight-driven tower clocks with verge escapements appeared in European cities. They made civic time audible and public.

title: Pendulum Clock
abstract: Huygens applied the pendulum to clock escapements, boosting accuracy orders of magnitude. The pendulum clock became Europe’s time standard.

title: Marine Chronometer
abstract: Harrison’s chronometers solved longitude at sea by keeping accurate shipboard time. Navigation became safer and global trade accelerated.

title: Quartz Watch
abstract: An electronic oscillator that keeps time with far higher precision than classical mechanics.

title: Atomic Clock
abstract: Microwave transitions in cesium defined the second and synchronized global systems. Atomic clocks underpin GPS, telecoms, and finance.

title: Egyptian Calendar
abstract: The ancient Egyptian civil calendar, described notably by the Greek historian Herodotus, comprised 365 days divided into 12 months of 30 days, to which 5 additional days called epagomenal days were added each year. From the New Kingdom (around 1550–1070 BC), the months were no longer designated by numbers, but by names linked to religious festivals celebrated mainly in Thebes.

title: Planets and the Days of the Week
Man‑nen Jimeisho — Clock of Temporal Hours
